awd_abstract_narration:
Over the past few decades, deep connections between pure mathematics and physics have developed. One such area of fruitful interaction is between string theory, a branch of theoretical physics connected with the structure of elementary particles, and enumerative geometry, which studies counts of the number of solutions to geometric problems (how many lines, for example, pass through four fixed lines in space). This project  will develop a new technique, which is inspired from the gauged linear sigma model (GLSM) in physics, to solve several enumerative problems.

In more detail, the project will develop a new technique (log GLSM) in higher genus Gromov-Witten theory. The goal is to prove conjectures from physics such as the holomorphic anomaly equations for quintic threefolds and more general complete intersection Calabi-Yau 3-folds. For this, a new moduli space will be constructed whose localization formula gives a way of computing Gromov-Witten invariants of a convex complete intersection from those of its ambient space, and new "effective invariants". Different applications will exploit the structure of the localization formula, and correspondences between effective invariants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME DU LAC

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Over the past several decades, deep connections between pure mathematics and physics have developed. One such area of fruitful interaction is between string theory, a branch of theoretical physics connected with the structure of elementary particles, and enumerative geometry, which studies counts of the number of solutions to geometric problems (for example, how many lines pass through four fixed skew lines in space). Gromov-Witten (GW) invariants are counts of algebraic curves in high-dimensional spaces, which lie at the center of this interplay.

Considerations in string theory have led to mathematical predictions about the fundamental structure of higher genus GW invariants. In particular 1993, Edward Witten introduced gauged linear sigma models (GLSM) in string theory in order to study phase transitions between supersymmetric gauge theories. This led to the LG/CY correspondence, a conjectural relationship between GW invariants and a different type of curve counting invariants called Fan-Jarvis-Ruan-Witten (FJRW) invariants.

The progress to establish these mathematical conjectures from string theory has remained slow until a series of recent breakthroughs. The research conducted
under this grant fits under one of these: the development of the technique of logarithmic gauged linear sigma models (log GLSM)


Intellectual Merit:

This grant has supported the production of 7 research papers and preprints, as well as the preparation of several upcoming papers. The theory developed under this grant lays the groundwork for future research in both computational and geometrical directions.

Two published foundational articles establish the theory of log GLSM, and bring in into the context of existing curve counting theories, such as GW theory and FJRW theory. In a third preprint, we lay foundations for computations using log GLSMs, in particular for uncovering structures in higher genus GW invariants. In particular, the preprint establishes a geometrical version of the LG/CY correspondence.

Broader Impacts:

The PI disseminated results obtained through this grant in several talks and minicourses. The grant also allowed the PI to organize a learning workshop for graduate students at Notre Dame, as well as to support an undergraduate student for a summer to work on a challenging mathematical research project related to the PI's research.


Last Modified: 02/10/2025
Modified by: Felix Janda
